terms.definition: Technical documentation that describes how to use and integrate with an Application Programming Interface, including endpoints, parameters, and response formats.
The systematic process of creating, reviewing, editing, and publishing documentation content through various stages and stakeholders.
A web-based user interface that runs on remote servers and is accessed through the internet, eliminating the need for local software installation.
A graphical user interface that displays key information, metrics, and controls in an organized, easy-to-understand visual format.
Individuals or groups who have an interest in or are affected by a project, including team members, clients, and end users.
A programming language commonly used for web development to create interactive and dynamic content on websites.
Automated processes that handle the deployment and distribution of content from creation environments to live, public-facing platforms.
A design approach that organizes information and functionality around discrete, manageable objects or entities rather than linear processes.
Digital containers that organize related documentation content into book-like structures for easier navigation and management.
Digital organizational structures that group and categorize virtual books or documentation collections, similar to physical library shelves.
The process of integrating new users or team members into a system, platform, or organization by providing necessary training and resources.
A pre-release version of software or content that is tested by users before the final production release.
The final stage where software, content, or documentation is live and available to end users in its completed form.
A structured workflow system that allows multiple team members to work together on content creation and review processes.
The final platforms, applications, or contexts where users will actually access and interact with the published documentation or content.
